Not really. My thinking was some=
thing like this... If you write multiple asserts, some of which you expect =
to fail (as in the original example), I was thinking that you were expectin=
g failures and wanted to know each of them ... thus human intervention. How=
ever, if you write the tests and expect them to pass, then having multiple =
assertions failing only requires human intervention for evaluation of failu=
res, which is no different. So I was on crack.
 
> The problem with this ap=
proach is not just that it leads to an explosion of
> test methods, it's th=
at it decouples code that you obviously want to keep
> ..
> other methods t=
o modify them too.
 
I suppose. Though running the tests will find them, so=
 they will eventually get fixed.
 
By the way, I think it is normal to have=
 multiple asserts in a test method. I understand some people would disagree=
, but often I want to test something bigger than a unit. Here's an actual e=
xample: I want to perform data validation on a composite object. I set up o=
ne test for each individual field. There will be some dependent validations=
. I need to set up tests for those. It is likely that when I have dependent=
 validations I might have multiple things I need to verify were shown to be=
 in error, thus multiple asserts.
 
If I use an external resource (e.g. a D=
AO, even a mocked one), if I expect a non-null result but get a null result=
, I'll have a failure with a null pointer exception. I'd rather put an asse=
rt with a message so I know right away what's going on.
 
So having multipl=
e asserts in a test method, at least for me, is par for the course.
 
>Sure=
, but you can get the same result with strings, which are even more
> reada=
ble:
 
For this trivial example, I agree the strings would work well, but I=
'd still have different test methods for the second reason I mention below:=

 
For the majority of examples there will be some amount of setup. Using m=
ultiple methods along with the setUp/tearDown (@Before/@After) feature of J=
Unit allows for test isolation. In this trivial example, it is not necessar=
y.
 
However, there is the issue of equivalence sets. In the original examp=
les, the person was validating different logical test scenarios and I would=
 argue those should be in different test methods. I would also argue that t=
he last two examples were in the same equivalence set (is that the right te=
rm?) and so the third test was useless. So from the original example, there=
 should have been 2 tests, one for a successful use and one for a failed us=
e. Furthermore, the failed example should have been written to assertFalse =
instead of true to move the overall example to more of a automated one. Thi=
s last point is overkill for the example provided, so in this case I'd prob=
ably build one unit test.
